title: One of Australia's biggest customers ditches our biggest export
text:
Energy experts say South Korea's pledge to phase out thermal coal should be a wake-up call for Australia's fossil fuel industry.﻿

This week South Korea - a major customer of Australian thermal coal exports - joined Powering Past Coal Alliance (PPCA), committing to abandon all its coal power by 2040.

The move was lauded by environment campaigners who have pushed major industrial nations to ditch fossil fuels and replace them with renewable energy sources.

READ MORE: Australia loses out in bid to host crucial climate conference

South Korea is phasing out coal, and that has major implications for Australian mining companies. (AP)

South Korea is the world's fourth largest importer of coal, which is used to power its industrial base and heat homes.﻿

But the country's steelmakers have been building steel plants that do not use coal, resulting in a gradual drop in demand for the fossil fuel.﻿

But South Korea's decision and similar moves by other nations also brings big implications for Australian coal exporters.

The value of Australian coal exports to South Korea is worth about $2.4 billion a year, data analytics company Kpler said.

The Australian Office of the Chief Economist has forecast a near 15 per cent decline in global thermal coal demand in the three years to 2027.

Thermal coal, along with iron ore, liquified gas and coking coal, make up Australia's four largest commodity exports from last year.

Climate Energy Finance director Tim Buckley said those major exporters would be "terminally challenged" over coming decades as countries shifted to renewable energy to meet commitments under the 2015 Paris agreement.

"This should send a strong reminder to Australia as the second largest exporter of thermal coal behind only Indonesia that our key trade partners are responding to climate science and their treaty obligations," he said.

"Australia needs to pivot our export focus to low emissions industries of the future, in particular exporting green iron and aluminium, critical minerals and lithium hydroxide to help our key trade partners jointly deliver on their decarbonisation objectives."

title: Fresh laws will stop dodgy real estate agents from underquoting home prices
text:
A﻿ustralian-first laws will soon make it illegal for Victorian real estate agents to underquote the reserve price of a property in the days before an auction.

Agents will be made to disclose a home's exact reserve price a week before it goes under the hammer in a major overhaul of underquoting legislation in the state.

Underquoting is already illegal in Victoria however the proposed ﻿reform will make it harder to advertise misleading prices closer to auction day.

Agents will be made to disclose a home's exact reserve price a week before it goes under the hammer. (Dion Georgopoulos)

The key change was announced today by Victoria's Consumer Affairs Minister Nick Staikos﻿ today after media reports of dishonest auction practices.

Under the current laws, agents can set a reserve or asking price which is above the previously advertised figure as late as the day of the auction﻿.

It leads to potential homebuyers wasting their Saturday at auctions for a home they an't afford.

The updated laws will require agents to publish the actual reserve price at least seven days before auction day.

Real estate agents who fail to disclose a reserve price within this time frame will be banned from proceeding to auction or sale.﻿

All marketing materials will be required to reflect the honest reserve price too.

﻿"Underquoting isn't fair and it's young Victorians and families paying the price," Staikos said today.

"That's why we're stamping it out by requiring reserve prices to be published at least seven days before an auction.

Victoria's Consumer Affairs Minister Nick Staikos. (Eddie Jim)

"We want the housing market to be fair – that's why we're continuing to crack down on underquoting with strong laws, a dedicated taskforce and active enforcement."

The Labor government said its underquoting taskforce has﻿ issued over 200 infringements totalling over $2.3 million in fines.

In response, the Victorian Greens said it supported the fresh underquoting laws but warned it may not have any impact on housing affordability.﻿

All marketing materials will be required to reflect the honest reserve price too. (Getty)

The Greens claimed underquoting has "run rampant" in the state, which has fuelled competition and driven prices up.

"Labor's finally catching. First-home buyers have been getting completely screwed for years, wasting time and spending thousands on inspections for homes they were never going to afford," said Victorian Greens housing spokesperson Gabrielle de Vietri.

"Being told the reserve early is helpful, but it doesn't change the reality that most young people can't afford the reserve in the first place."

Similar laws were introduced this month in NSW , which penalises dodgy real estate agents who put misleading price estimates in property listings.﻿

title: Aussie cities with the most expensive commutes revealed
text:
Australians who drive to work are losing a staggering 212 million hours a year sitting in traffic, the equivalent of 8.8 million working days and about $9.7 billion in lost time.

Analysts at iSelect used ABS, census and congestion data to find out how long Australians were spending stuck in rush hour traffic, and how much it was costing them in terms of lost earnings and fuel costs.

Melbourne has the worst driving commute in the country, losing the equivalent of $4628 a year.

Australians are spending billions of dollars to get to work each year. (Getty)

In second place among the captials was Sydney ($4568)﻿, followed by Perth ($3496), Brisbane ($3447), Adelaide ($3377), Canberra ($2244), Hobart ($1856), and Darwin ($1390).

Some regional centres also notched up high totals, including Newcastle ($2587) and the Gold Coast ($2443).

Across Australian cities, the average driver spends roughly $2788 a year due to congestion.

Different professions also bear different costs.

Medical practitioners spend more than four extra days a year in traffic, iSelect found, which was the equivalent of $6784 a year.

Other high-cost occupations include air and marine transport professionals, who spend more than three days a year in traffic, translating to a combined cost of $5436. Health diagnostic and promotion professionals spend $5418.

The full research can be found here .﻿

title: New mRNA flu vaccine far more effective than existing jabs: study
text:
A newly developed mRNA-based flu vaccine is almost 35 per cent more effective against the most common form of influenza , according to a new study.

The phase three trial, whose results were published this morning in the New England Journal of Medicine , involved more than 18,000 people aged between 18 and 64.

Half of the participants were given a standard flu vaccine, while the other half received the new mRNA option developed by Pfizer.

A phase three trial of an mRNA flu vaccine developed by Pfizer shows it is more than 34 per cent more effective against influenza A than existing vaccines. (AP)

The study found that the latter was 34.5 per cent more effective at protecting people against influenza A.

"The mRNA vaccine performed better than conventional flu vaccines," Professor Archa Fox from the University of Western Australia, who wasn't involved in the study, said.

"Only 0.63 per cent of people injected with the mRNA flu vaccine came down with the flu, compared to 0.95 per cent of people injected with the conventional flu vaccine."

The results are similar to a trial of another mRNA flu vaccine developed by Moderna, which showed a 26.6 per cent effectiveness increase compared to a standard vaccine.

However, there weren't enough cases of influenza B in today's study to determine the Pfizer vaccine's effectiveness against that type of virus, and the mRNA jab was also linked to a higher rate of mild to moderate side effects.

Influenza killed more than 1000 people in Australia last year and is on track to kill even more in 2025. (CDC)

"Lab tests suggested that the new vaccine may not be as effective against B strains," Associate Professor Seth Cheetham from the University of Queensland said.

"The mRNA vaccine was safe, but an elevated rate of side effects, such as headache and injection site pain, was detected compared to traditional vaccines."

The level of severe side effects, though, was similarly low for both vaccines.

However, the phase three trial showed another limitation of the Pfizer vaccine: a lack of benefit for vulnerable elderly patients.

"Most crucially, it showed no significant benefit for adults over 65, the group most at risk from severe flu, highlighting that this is a promising step forward but not a complete solution for all," molecular virologist Vinod Balasubramaniam said.

Vaccination rates against flu have dropped significantly in recent years in Australia, despite a surge in the number of cases of the potentially deadly illness.

Experts are hoping the development of mRNA vaccines, using similar technology to what was behind the successful COVID-19 vaccines, could lead to better protection against the virus.

"Manufacturing mRNA vaccines is significantly faster than traditional methods, which rely on growing the virus in eggs or cells, a process that can take six months or more," Dr Emma Grant from La Trobe University said.

"Faster production means vaccine strains can be selected closer to the flu season, reducing the risk of mismatch with circulating viruses.

"Moreover, as demonstrated with COVID-19 vaccines, mRNA technology can activate multiple arms of the immune system, including long-lived killer T cells that recognise multiple different influenza strains…

"This capability moves us closer to the long-sought goal of a 'universal' influenza vaccine, one that provides broader and longer-lasting protection."

title: NSW man ordered to turn in plates featuring dictator's nickname
text:
A Sydney man says an order to turn over his personalised licence plates featuring the infamous nickname of a WWII dictator is a violation of his free speech rights.

Eddie sent a message to Ben Fordham Live on 2GB saying the message he received from Transport for NSW was "another damning indictment of the woke left imposing their thoughts on our society".

His personalised licence plates, for which he claims he paid just shy of $900, read ILDUCE, or "Il Duce" - Italian for "The Leader".

READ MORE: Meta to start closing teenage accounts weeks social media ban starts ﻿

Duce is descended from the Latin word "dux", from which the noble title "duke"﻿ is also derived.

"Il Duce" was also the widely used nickname of fascist dictator Benito Mussolini, who ruled Italy from 1922 until his overthrow and death in 1945, and who was a close ally of Adolf Hitler.

Eddie told 2GB's Ben Fordham that he chose the plates to reflect his business role.

A man has been ordered to turn in his personalised licence plates emblazoned with "ILDUCE". (Supplied)

﻿"(The car) is under my company ownership, the words really mean 'the leader', I'm the director of the company," he said.

He acknowledged there was a "connotation" to Mussolini but maintained the words themselves were innocent.

He claimed there was a double standard in place, with other "offensive" licence plates allowed on the roads.

"Il Duce", meaning "The Leader" in Italian, was the nickname of fascist dictator Benito Mussolini. (Supplied)

Mussolini, left, was an ally of Adolf Hitler in WWII. (AP)

Transport for NSW confirmed a member of the public had reported the plates﻿, which were subject to an assessment by the department.

"The decision to withdraw the plates is based on a wider perception they could be directly related to fascist dictator Benito Mussolini," a spokesperson said.

"The ILDUCE number plates were originally issued due to an oversight in the vetting process."

Transport for NSW will refund the balance of the annual fee owing for the plates and issue replacement plates at no cost.

Eddie will also be able to order a new set of personalised plates up to the same cost as he paid for the ILDUCE plates, free of charge.

Until then, he will be given general issue plates on the spot when he turns in the ILDUCE plates before the deadline of November 24.

title: Australia Post brings back weekend deliveries ahead of Christmas rush
text:
Australian shoppers can now expect parcels to arrive any day of the week, as Australia Post reintroduces temporary weekend deliveries starting this Saturday to manage the enormous volume of packages expected this festive season.

The move, which covers all metro capital cities and selected regional locations, comes as Australia Post prepares for the surge driven by major sales events like Black Friday and Cyber Monday.

The weekend service will remain in place until Christmas.

Australia Post will be delivering on weekends in the lead-up to the Christmas rush. (iStock)

Gary Starr, Australia Post's Executive General Manager for Parcels, Post, and eCommerce Services, said the extra service would ensure deliveries remained timely during the peak period.

"With Black Friday and Cyber Monday just around the corner, we're expecting to see a significant spike in parcel volumes and online spending activity," Starr said.

"Last year we delivered nearly 103 million parcels over the Black Friday sales period, and we're ready to go even bigger this holiday season. Weekend deliveries are just one of the ways Australia Post is stepping up to support our customers."

To handle the expected influx of parcels, Australia Post has had to expand its resources.

This includes adding more free Parcel Lockers and opening new, dedicated parcel-focused Post Offices with 24/7 self-serve options in metro areas across NSW, VIC, QLD, and ACT.

Christmas deadlines for packages

To avoid disappointment, shoppers are being told to stick to these cut-off dates to guarantee arrival by Christmas Day.

Service Same state (metro) Interstate (metro) Parcel Post Monday, December 22 Friday, December 19 Express Post Tuesday, December 23 Tuesday, December 23

People sending to or from Western Australia, Northern Territory, Tasmania, or regional and remote locations, should allow a few extra days.

title: One disease wiped out Steph's family in a year. Survival rates have barely changed
text:
Exclusive: For anyone, having a loved one diagnosed with cancer is devastating.

Especially when it's one of the least survivable kinds.

But﻿ Steph McGuire, 31, lost her mother, father and aunt to the same kind of cancer over just 12 months.

Steph McGuire, 31, has lost her mother, father and aunt to the same kind of cancer in just 12 months. (Supplied)

"It's hard to know what to feel it's just so surreal," McGuire, from Melbourne, said.

"When mum got it, obviously it hit hard.

"Then a few months later, my dad got diagnosed, which was horrible.

"It was stage four, my mum was stage three.

"Then my aunty got diagnosed a year or so later.

"You're like, 'Surely it's not the same.'"

The mother to Harvey, four, and Hazel, 10 months, with ﻿husband Shaydan, is now worried about her own health.

Her mum, Vicki Jackson, who worked at a law firm, died aged 65 in July 2024, just over two years after being diagnosed with pancreatic cancer.

Her early symptom was itching palms, a sign of bile in the bloodstream.

Steph's father died from pancreatic cancer a year after her mother. (Supplied)

Her former CEO father, Steve, who was given the devastating news that he too had pancreatic cancer just months after his ex-wife's diagnosis, died a year after that, aged 66.

He had bowel issues, which flagged a problem, though he defied expectations to live for three years﻿ after chemo and a trial treatment.

In between losing her parents, Steph's aunt and her mother's sister, Valerie Boyd, was also diagnosed with and died from the disease.

She had diabetes, which can be an indicator.

Steph is now doing genetic testing to see if she's likely to develop it, though testing done on her parents indicated it was not a genetic type.

An early diagnosis is crucial to surviving.﻿

"It definitely freaks me out, ﻿once the symptoms are there, it's really too late," she says.

Advocates are also pushing for more money to help save lives.

Steph's mother Vicki, right, and her aunt Valerie both died from the disease. (Supplied)

Michelle Stewart, CEO of Pankind, said earlier detection and faster treatment - as well as funding for research - is needed.

"Survival has improved, but not fast enough and when several members of a family are diagnosed, it underscores the urgent need to understand familial and genetic risk," Stewart said.

Pankind has a family health checker online so Aussies can assess their risk.

Last month, a new study for a screening program was announced, trialling surveillance methods for those at higher risk.

It aligns Australia with the global PRECEDE study, which aims to lift five-year survival rates from 13 to 50 per cent within a decade.

A spokesman for the Department of Health, Disability and Ageing said the Australian Government supports health and medical research with $650 million annually from the Medical Research Future Fund (MRFF) and around $1 billion a year through the National Health and Medical Research Council's (NHMRC) Medical Research Endowment Account (MREA).

It has invested more than $13 million for research focused on pancreatic cancer in the past decade, he said.

"Between 2015 and 2024, the NHMRC has expended $41.5 million towards research relevant to pancreatic cancer.

"On 2 May 2024, Minister (Mark) Butler announced the MRFF Low Survival Cancers Mission (LSCM).

"It will provide $150 million over 10 years, from 2027-28, for research to improve care and health outcomes for people with low survival cancers, including pancreatic cancer."

READ MORE: Professor flooded with death threats after what he wants banned from Queensland ﻿

Health Minister Mark Butler has announced more money for cancer. (Getty)

Pancreatic cancer facts

Pancreatic cancer is the third-leading cause of cancer death in Australia.

Symptoms include abdominal and back pain, jaundice, loss of appetite, unexplained weight loss, fatty stool, new onset or hard to manage diabetes and nausea.

Patients diagnosed have just a 13 per cent chance of surviving for five years, according to Pankind.

Only three out of 10 people diagnosed will be alive after a year.

It's a number which has not increased for 15 years, unlike the figures for other cancers such as breast cancer, which is now at a 93 per cent five-year survival rate .

title: 'Champion young man' who died in cricketing accident farewelled
text:
The Shane Warne stand at Junction Oval was a sea of cricket shirts, football jumpers and scarves as friends and family gathered to farewell Melbourne teenager Ben Austin, who died in a tragic cricket accident last month.

Ben, 17, was struck in the neck by a ball while practising in the nets at Wally Tew Reserve in Ferntree Gully, in Melbourne's outer east.

He later died in hospital.

Junction Oval in St Kilda — the home of Cricket Victoria — was a fitting venue for the sports-mad boy who loved cricket and football.

A framed photo of Ben sat on a table on the oval alongside a football bearing his name, signed Collingwood and Waverley Park Hawks football jumpers, and the 2023 AFL premiership cup. A cricket bat with his name and the number 521 leant on the table.

The 2023 AFL premiership cup sat alongside a football and cricket bat. (ABC News)

Funeral celebrant Jennifer Mettner said the oval was a special place for Ben and his father Jace.

"This is a place where Jace and Ben have been together," she said.

"They really loved being here. Taking in the atmosphere, and everything that it has to offer."

Ms Mettner also said starting the service at 11am was significant.

"11am was the time that the first ball of cricket was traditionally bowled," she said.

A normal Tuesday turns into 'a nightmare'

Ben's grandfather, David Austin, said the teenager was a beloved son of Tracey and Jace and a big brother to Cooper and Zach.

He said Ben, who attended Rowville Sports Academy, hoped to become a physical education teacher if a sporting career didn't eventuate.

Ben's grandfather David Austin gave the eulogy. (ABC News)

"He then said, 'If my cricket and football don't reach the top level where I'm getting paid, I'll be a boundary umpire in the AFL. They get good money'," David Austin recalled.

"And I thought, 'That'll work for Ben. He can run all day'."

David Austin said the day of the accident started as any other Tuesday, with the three Austin brothers coming around for breakfast before school.

But it soon turned into "a nightmare and our most tragic day".

"Jace, Tracey and their family want to be very clear about one thing," he said as light rain began to fall

"This was an accident. No-one's fault, no-one's blame.

"Everything that's been said or written about Ben in the media is absolutely, 100 per cent correct. Ben loved his cricket and football. Ben was also a passionate supporter of the Collingwood Football Club.

"To have an outstanding young man, a ripper young man, taken so young — it makes no sense. It's not fair, it's not right. Sometimes life sucks."

"Rest in peace our champion young man, Ben Austin."

Jace Austin places a Collingwood scarf on his son's casket. (ABC News)

Ben's dad Jace, wearing a blue cricket cap, said his son "lit up the world".

"The best goal you ever scored or four you ever hit wasn't on the field, it was when your soul chose us as your family," he said.

He remembered fondly how Ben loved aeroplanes.

"He loved watching planes up close, tracking them on the app, telling me their size and destination.

"We would guess where the next one going to or from. A game I continue to play."

title: 'It is hard': The double life of Mackin as an Irish AFLW player
text:
Of all the sacrifices athletes make in pursuit of their dreams, for Melbourne AFLW premiership player Blaithin Mackin, it's her mum's Sunday roast back in Ireland.

The 26-year-old Irishwoman spends four to five months in Australia playing with the Demons, and the other lion's share of the year back playing Gaelic for her county Armagh in the Ladies Gaelic Football Association (LGFA).

As one of six siblings — two who have kids — she says the hardest part of her playing career is missing important moments with them back home.

"I feel like it is hard. You're not fully settled anywhere, which sometimes I find tricky," Mackin told ABC Sport.

"I'm quite lucky that I have a good base at home — I still live with my parents — and then over here, I'm lucky with the girls and the friendships that I have. They're two good bases, but you are very much split."

Blaithin Mackin of the Demons spends a third of the year in Australia and the rest in Ireland. (Getty: Dylan Burns/AFL Photos)

Mackin has lived with Demons teammates Alyssa Bannan, Megan Fitzsimon and Tyla Hanks previously. She now shares an apartment with her brother Connaire, who has joined her for the season.

"Which has been great," she said. "Because it helps with homesickness."

Yet while many of her friends are putting down roots, she straddles living in two different countries to play both games.

"One of my best mates bought a house the other day and I was like, 'Whoa, I'm so far off', because I'm not at home full-time, I'm not here full-time," she said, noting that she wouldn't have it any other way as she doesn't want to give either sport up.

Blaithin Mackin plays for Armagh with her sister Aimee. (Getty: Ramsey Cardy/Sportsfile)

Mackin is one of 40 Irish players in the AFLW, who make up almost 8 per cent of the entire competition.

On her own team is 35-year-old Sinead Goldrick, who Mackin said is surreal to play with, as she looked up to her as a kid in Gaelic.

Many Irish players are attracted to the professionalism of the Australian game, whereas Gaelic is still amateur.

This means that Gaelic players have to fit training in around full-time work, often after hours, with little time for extras such as recovery, said Mackin.

Irish influx is shaping the game in AFLW The AFLW has had an influx of Irish talent in recent years, with the new talent helping change the game.

GWS' Eilish O'Dowd, for example, is a teacher back in Ireland and works each week day from nine to three or four before heading to training after dinner.

The appeal in Australia is being able to focus full-time on being a footballer and getting the most out of their bodies as athletes.

"You don't have this time for long either, where you're a footballer, so I just try to buy into that as much as I can," Mackin said.

"I love that side of it. To see how far you can push yourself as an athlete in terms of fitness.

"I've probably been a wee bit unlucky with injuries in the past two seasons to really fully get going with that. But I feel in the first two seasons, I was able to push myself again to be a really good version of myself as an athlete."

The competition, some argue, also benefits from a high influx of Irish talent within it.

Almost eight percent of the AFLW competition is made up of Irish players. (Getty: Michael Willson/AFL Photos)

Cats AFLW operations and recruiting manager Ben Waller said they naturally play with "such attacking flair", which brings a lot of energy to the game of AFLW.

In the third quarter of Melbourne's semifinal victory against Adelaide, Mackin got the handball-receive from captain Kate Hore and whacked the Sherrin onto the side of her boot to kick a critical goal to spark the Demons' comeback.

"Everyone was like, 'That was the biggest Gaelic kick I've ever seen', and I was like, 'Well, I didn't have time to think', so I just kicked, and when I just kick, that's what happens," laughed Mackin.

Now, along with a second flag with Melbourne, Mackin's dream is to have her family be able to see her run around.

They stay up at all hours to watch her play. At least two AFLW games are broadcast in Ireland every week, and all the finals.

Loading Instagram content

Even her Irish club's chairman once joked at a dinner dance — their version of a best and fairest — that he never thought he'd be up at 2am watching Australian rules but there he was, cheering her on.

"[But] I've got five nephews and one niece. It was one of their birthdays the other day, actually. The oldest, he turned seven the other day, and I'm like, 'Damn, I missed it,'" Mackin said.

"I would love it if I could take all my nephews and nieces to watch a game. It could be cool to have them here. But obviously, that's nearly impossible to do.

"My sister's always, like, if we win the lotto, we're straight on the flight over. And I'm like, 'Please win the lotto.'''

title: This riverside block floods. So why would you build on it?
text:
Richard Rowles sees the Brisbane River as a living thing that "breathes in and out two times a day".

"It's got its own character and it changes all the time. When it gets angry, you don't want to be anywhere near it. But the rest of the time, it's pretty good," he says.

This perspective was shaped by a childhood spent launching off the jetty behind his family's riverside block in Sherwood, where his Irish ancestors established themselves after arriving in Australia 160 years ago.

"We grew up here as kids, so we spent a lot of time in canoes, swimming and fishing and shrimping in the river," he remembers.

Richard (far left), pictured in the 1970s along the river playing with kids from the neighbourhood. (Supplied)

Richard and his wife Janette passed this lifestyle onto their now-adult sons William and Ollie, whom they raised in the neighbouring suburb of Chelmer.

Stream Grand Designs Australia on ABC iview Architecture Professor Anthony Burke is back with a brand new series of Grand Designs Australia following some truly brave home builders taking on the challenge of a lifetime.

After Richard's mother died in 2015, leaving the block to him and his brother to divide between them, the couple decided it was time to move back to the place he had first called home.

"Selling Chelmer was really difficult because it was our family home, we raised the kids there," Janette tells Grand Designs Australia.

"[But] we liked the connection with the fact we come from somewhere and we're returning to where we came from," Richard adds.

That's how the plan for a new build beside a river prone to catastrophic floods took shape.

There was the 1974 event that altered Brisbane forever; the deadly 2011 floods; and the 2022 deluge — and that's just in recent memory.

The original house on the Rowles family block (pictured) was inundated during the 2011 floods. (Supplied)

Indeed, after the Brisbane River again rose to dangerous levels in 2022 and flooded Richard and Janette's Sherwood block once more, the builders who had just arrived on site were forced to stop work.

The couple were already used to what Janette describes as the "torture" that is "watching the slow, insidious creep of water … over a few days".

Despite the 2022 floods, Richard says the couple decided there was "no turning back" after they sold their Chelmer home. (Supplied)

But no-one expected a 200-odd-metre stretch of the riverbank to subside in that flood, causing the land to drop down by up to a metre in areas on their block.

Architect James Russell says approvals for the project were suddenly retracted, forcing them to redesign the house.

James Russell says a number of houses near Richard and Janette's block were condemned after the 2022 landslip (pictured). (Supplied)

But, without that 2022 flood, the couple's riverfront home wouldn't be quite so resilient.

A house you can hose out

Almost two-and-a-half years of work and upwards of $2 million later, Richard and Janette have ended up with a light-filled house set 11 metres back from the river and almost half a metre above council requirements.

"All the habitable floor levels are well and truly above what the Brisbane City Council sees as the 100-year-plus flood levels," Russell explains.

The mysterious front screen battens along the exterior of Janette and Richard's house offer only a hint of what life is like inside. (ABC/Fremantle Media: Tom Blessing)

Anchored by 26 piers placed 13.5 metres into the earth, Russell's redesign kept possible future landslips front of mind. He says the house should "have 10 to 20mm movement maximum if the entire bank [were to give] way".

In case of a record-breaking flood, all valuables are on the upper level and the blockwork undercroft of the house is submersible, with elevated power points and light switches.

In the event of a huge flood, Russell says Richard and Janette might see water rise up to the landscaped courtyard in the centre of the house. (ABC/Fremantle Media: Tom Blessing)

"The materials are really robust, almost like rock coming out of the ground," Russell says.

"Some people might find it odd that the power points and switches are up two metres high, but this way the flood can go through and you can let it go down and everything can be hosed out."

Connecting those spaces to the upper level is a concrete set of stairs that leads to an internal courtyard.

The upper level of Richard and Janette's house was also built with water-resistant materials. (ABC/Fremantle Media: Tom Blessing)

Upstairs, 170 water-resistant and removable melamine panels have been screwed to the exposed epoxy-painted steel frame, and heavy-duty ironbark floorboards that could survive days submerged were used throughout the space.

The result is a house Richard and Janette feel safe living in — even without conventional flood insurance.

"If you want flood insurance cover in these areas, you'll pay a fortune — certainly $30,000 to $40,000 a year, which is a lot of money if you're going into retirement," Richard says.

"Our opinion is we spent a considerable amount of money on flood 'insurance' with the ground engineering and in-ground structure, with the materials used in construction, and the height we built at."

After the couple explained what they had done with the build to their insurance broker, Richard says they were able to insure their home excluding flood cover.

The future of flood plain living

James Davidson, whose architecture firm helped inform Queensland's flood resilience framework, acknowledges Richard and Janette's house is "on the big end of town".

But with 15 years' experience helping clients improve flood resilience on budgets of $50,000 to $100,000 per home, he says the same principles can be used for any property, "no matter the cost".

Architect James Davidson says flood-resilient design elements like those used in the Sherwood home buy their residents "some time". (ABC/Fremantle Media: Tom Blessing)

"And the cost-benefit is significant. If you put $50,000 into [flood resilience] now, it'll save incredible amounts of money over time."

Building and retrofitting for flood resilience: Understand projected flood levels

Use resilient materials up high

Move services and switches up

Choose non-cavity construction

Ditch plasterboard

Use concrete, tiled and rendered surfaces

Raise houses where possible

Treat pine framing

Whether building a new home or retrofitting, he says the most critical thing to understand is your current and projected flood levels.

"Council adjusts those levels with every new event," he explains.

" Understand that if you do build to the [current] council flood level, it might go higher next time and you might still be at risk. "

People often think making a property more flood-resilient is costly, but Davidson says the materials are affordable and readily available. (ABC/Fremantle Media: Tom Blessing)

He also recommends using resilient materials above those defined floodlines, as Janette and Richard did, and getting services like air conditioning and hot water units as high as possible.

The same goes for switches and powerpoints, so long as this is accessible.

And where possible, Davidson suggests avoiding cavity construction.

"Cavities cause mould growth and humidity problems," he explains. "Concrete slabs, tiled and rendered surfaces are good. And when it comes to cabinetry, there are flood-resilient materials."

Richard and Janette's hose-out undercroft (pictured), atop which sits an elegant cantilevered steel structure that houses their living spaces. (ABC/Fremantle Media: Tom Blessing)

When retrofitting, Davidson recommends raising houses wherever possible, using tiles, concrete slabs or hardwood for flooring, ditching plasterboard in the walls and treating any pine framing with mould-resistant paint.

Retrofitting a home for natural disasters Rebuilding a home exactly as it was doesn't always make sense for those impacted by natural disasters.

But he sees none of these measures as "solutions" — in Davidson's mind, that would be retreating from the worst-hit areas.

"These things will buy some time … I'm not totally convinced that we should be building right onto the Brisbane River in the future.

"And I don't want my work to be seen as the 'get-out-of-jail-free card' where people say, 'Oh, we'll be fine, we've done it resiliently.'"

There's no such thing, Davidson argues, as a flood-proof house.

"But there are resilient homes and homeowners who are happy to stay in [higher-risk] locations."

Watch the new season of Grand Designs Australia free on ABC TV and ABC iview.

title: Brisbane girls school under fire after teachers' dossier on students leaked
text:
Students and parents at one of Brisbane's most prestigious girls schools have been left appalled and upset after a document where teachers recorded notes about students' personalities, medical diagnoses, physical appearances and parents' marital status was leaked.

Teachers at Somerville House wrote the document about students when they were in year seven, in 2021, which included descriptions of students such as the condition of their hair, their popularity with classmates, and their demeanour, referring to some students as "odd" or "rude".

It also included descriptions of how students responded to certain subjects and assessments and their behaviour in class, as well as details of their medical diagnoses and treatment — including the type of medical care and medication.

The notes also included descriptions of the marital status of parents and called some "intense" when describing their involvement in their daughter's learning.

It is understood students were able to access the document after stumbling across it when they were looking for files uploaded by a teacher in Microsoft Teams.

The incident has occurred while the students are studying for year 11 exams next week.

Principal Sandra Hastie wrote to parents late last night to alert them to the issue, which she described as a "data breach within our school IT system", but did not apologise.

"Some students have been able to access and read private historical notes as a result of the data breach," the emailed letter said.

" Those notes contain comments that fall short of our standards and our values. "

Dr Hastie told parents the school was investigating the notes and why the data breach occurred.

"The school will update you with any relevant information and will comply with its legal obligations to investigate and deal with the data breach," the emailed letter said.

Concerned parents then wrote to the principal raising multiple issues and complaints, including about the nature of the comments written about each student, and the school's handling of the issue.

Somerville House has been contacted for comment but has yet to respond to the ABC's questions.

The school, established in 1899, is the only Presbyterian and Methodist Schools Association pre-prep to year 12 facility for day and boarding students in Brisbane.

Prep fees begin at $23,300, and for senior school years, parents pay $30,144 per year.

title: Australia hands COP31 to Türkiye but Bowen to lead negotiations
text:
Adelaide will not hold next year's UN climate summit, with Climate Minister Chris Bowen revealing Australia was willing to cede hosting rights to Türkiye in exchange for it handing him the reins of the negotiations and cementing a major role for the Pacific at the summit.

There had been a growing expectation that Australia would drop its bid to host COP31 in Adelaide as it struggled to convince Türkiye withdraw from the contest.

Under UN rules, if the two countries were unable to strike a deal, then the meeting location would automatically revert to Germany, which hosts the United Nations body responsible for the Paris Agreement.

Live: Albanese says COP31 compromise with Türkiye is an 'outstanding result' Australia has ceded the COP31 climate summit to Türkiye but Climate Change Minister Chris Bowen will be the president of the summit pending Ankara's approval. Follow live.

Mr Bowen told reporters in Belem that while negotiations were ongoing, both countries were willing to make "significant concessions" to strike a deal.

"Significant concession is what's required when you are trying to find consensus," he said.

"Obviously, it would be great if Australia could have it all. But we can't have it all. This process works on consensus."

While details of the sharing arrangements are still being finalised, Mr Bowen said Türkiye would still hold the formal title of COP president and would "handle the venues and the operation" of the COP, but that he would be the "president of the COP for the purposes of negotiations".

"I would have all the powers of the COP presidency to manage, handle the negotiations, to appoint co-facilitators, to prepare draft text, to issue the cover decision," he said.

Prime Minister Anthony Albanese, who earlier this week acknowledged that the UN's rules did not allow for a co-presidency, said this option presented a workaround and was an "outstanding result".

"It wasn't possible under the rules to have a joint presidency, but Türkiye has agreed that Minister Bowen and Australia will handle the negotiations in the lead-up to the COP," he said.

Pacific leaders consulted

The decision has bitterly disappointed climate advocates who championed Adelaide's bid, saying it would supercharge Australia's renewable energy industry and leverage the Pacific's moral authority to drive more ambition on global climate action.

South Australian Premier Peter Malinauskas said he was "disappointed" but understood the prime minister's decision.

"He has taken a position to try and navigate the frankly obscene process that exists internationally," he said.

"We put our best foot forward and won the rights as a city and a state to host COP if it was won internationally, and internationally that was not able to be achieved."

Gavan McFadzean from the Australian Conservation Foundation said it was "a massive missed opportunity for Australia and the Pacific".

"Communities in the Pacific have been denied an important global platform to show how global inaction on climate change presents them with an existential threat," he said.

Shiva Gounden, head of the Pacific campaign at Greenpeace Australia Pacific, said it was "disappointing" but added "the Pacific's fight for survival does not rise or fall on a single hosting decision".

"For us, climate action has never been about prestige. It is about protecting and preserving our homelands, our cultures, and our future with dignity and humility."

But some climate experts were more optimistic about the compromise.

Erwin Jackson from Monash University's Climateworks Centre said the outcome would ensure "Australia and the Pacific will remain central to global climate transition."

"The region has everything to gain by building global momentum towards clean energy," he said.

"Australia's leadership role as the president holding the pen on text negotiation outcomes and leaders meeting in the Pacific will be highly influential in the outcomes of COP31.

"Strong regional leadership will be critical to accelerating the shift to a low-emissions future across Australia, the Pacific and the world."

Mr Bowen said both countries had to reach an agreement in order to avoid "12 months with a lack of leadership, no COP president in place, no plan".

"I know some people [will] be disappointed in that outcome," he said.

"Other people, of course, would be even more disappointed if it had gone to Bonn [in Germany] without a COP president in place. This is a better outcome than that."

Mr Bowen also confirmed that Australia was looking to ensure a "pre-COP" leaders meeting would be held in the Pacific under the deal, as well as a major fundraising round for the Pacific Resilience Facility.

Australia has been canvassing these options with Pacific leaders over the past 48 hours as diplomats have scrambled to land a deal.

Mr Albanese said he had spoken directly to Papua New Guinea's Prime Minister James Marape and Fiji's Prime Minister Sitiveni Rabuka and that the pre-COP Pacific event would ensure "the issues confronting this region, the very existence of island states such as Tuvalu and Kiribati … will be front and centre".

PNG Foreign Minister Justin Tkatchenko told news agency AFP Pacific leaders were "all not happy, and disappointed it's ended up like this".

title: Reserve property prices to be published in underquoting crackdown
text:
Real estate agents in Victoria will be required to publish a property's reserve price at least seven days before it goes to auction under a state government crackdown on illegal underquoting.

The Victorian government on Thursday morning unveiled Australian-first laws requiring real estate agents to publish reserve prices — the minimum amount a seller will accept for a property — ahead of an auction or fixed-date sale.

The laws will mean real estate agents who fail to disclose the reserve price within the timeframe cannot proceed to auction or sale. They are set to be introduced next year.

The Victorian government introduced a taskforce to tackle underquoting in 2022. (ABC News: Ian Cutmore)

Underquoting occurs when a property is deliberately advertised for less than its estimated selling price or the owner's asking price.

Despite underquoting being illegal, the Victorian government has acknowledged it remains a significant issue in the real estate industry.

A taskforce it established late in 2022 to crack down on the practice has received more than 5,000 complaints.

Hopeful homebuyers have told the ABC about their "demoralising" and "exhausting" experiences attending auctions for properties advertised within an acceptable price range that they ultimately couldn't afford.

Victorian Minister for Consumer Affairs Nick Staikos said the changes unveiled on Thursday were "a big step forward".

"Underquoting isn't fair, and it's young Victorians and families who are the ones paying for it," he said.

"This will mean that no longer will young prospective first home buyers have to waste their time on a property sales campaign when they never could afford the property in the first place."

Minnister Nick Staikos said the changes would stop young homebuyers attending auctions for properties they couldn't afford. (ABC News)

In recent years, the Victorian government has increased penalties for agents caught underquoting, made its taskforce permanent and strengthened advertising guidelines.

Mr Staikos said the new laws would provide Victorians with further transparency in property transactions.

"[It] ensures there is fairness and equity for everyone when making a big financial decision of purchasing a home," he said.

Changes won't address affordability, opposition says

Victorian Opposition Leader Jess Wilson, on her second day in the role, said the government's proposed regulations would have little impact on affordability.

"In principle, I don't have any issues with more market transparency, but by telling an aspirational home owner what the reserve price is seven days in advance, it does nothing to make the home more affordable," she said.

"It just demonstrates how expensive and probably out of reach it is."

Jess WIlson questioned the effectiveness of the changes. (AAP: Joel Carrett)

The Victorian Greens, who introduced a bill proposing similar changes in August, said while the party welcomed Labor's move, the system was still "stacked against first home buyers".

The party's housing spokesperson, Gabrielle de Vietri, said Labor's proposal should go further and make agents disclose reserve prices as soon as a property is on the market.

"Being told the reserve early is helpful, but it doesn't change the reality that most young people can't afford the reserve in the first place," she said

"Right now, Labor's making the housing crisis worse by demolishing public housing and pushing prices up with no plan to address affordability."

Real Estate Institute of Victoria chief executive Toby Balazs said the new laws would punish vendors.

"We do think it's an over-correction and ill-considered," he told ABC Radio Melbourne.

"There are ways in which we can bring greater price transparency to the market, but we need to balance that with the rights of vendors to maximise their profits."

title: Trial to offer mental health care 'from the comfort of home'
text:
A New South Wales-first trial of an in-home mental health treatment service will result in its host town losing access to its hospital-based mental health unit.

The Hospital in the Home model, which involves doctors travelling to patients' homes to deliver treatment, will be trialled for mental health patients in the mid north coast town of Kempsey from early next year.

"This is a positive innovation for NSW Health where we have the opportunity to be a leader across the state with developing this pilot," said Mid North Coast Local Health District (MNCLHD) director of mental health services, Sarah Fox.

" This [trial] will allow us to reduce stigma and provide safe care in the comfort of people's homes. "

She said patients would be "reallocated" from Kempsey District Hospital’s mental health unit, which could accommodate 10 patients as a voluntary inpatient facility, to at-home care or treatment at neighbouring hospitals when the trial started.

The mental health unit at Kempsey District Hospital will no longer take patients when the pilot starts in 2026. (ABC Coffs Coast: Charles Rushforth)

Services restructured

The Hospital in the Home pilot will include expanded funding for community services, including mental health programs aimed at First Nations mental health patients in the town, where 12 per cent of the population is Indigenous.

In a statement, the MNCLHD said involuntary mental health patients will be transferred to Port Macquarie Base Hospital's Mental Health Unit, 55km away.

That unit will be provided with increased resources and beds.

The LHD said there had been consultation about mental health services and community needs during the past 12 months.

Kempsey District Hospital's mental health unit is the only service in the town of 31,000 people that accepts voluntary inpatients who can stay for multiple days for treatment.

Kempsey Shire Councillor Alexandra Wyatt is concerned about the closure of the unit, which she said had provided life-saving mental health treatment to her relatives.

"It offered them respite, to have a good night's sleep and a good meal, and to not have to deal with whatever is going on at home or out in the community," she said.

"Moving to an at-home hospital care situation, I think that's actually high risk.

" I feel that for our situation, [at home mental health care] could have resulted in a death. "

NSW Minister for Mental Health Rose Jackson said the mental health unit can reopen if the trial is unsuccessful.

"We want to make sure that if there's a decision in the future around re-opening that facility in Kempsey, we've got space for that," she said.

Rose Jackson says the government will roll out the trial across New South Wales if it proves successful. (ABC Broken Hill: Bill Ormonde)

"I hope community-based care is supported … but at the moment we're keeping an open mind.

"If it does work well, if this is something that the local community feels is really positive, watch this space and we might look to roll it out state-wide."

Inpatient services needed

Victoria and Tasmania offer mental health treatment under the Hospital in the Home model, which has been lauded for offering life-changing care.

Psychiatrist Patrick McGorry runs a clinic that offers mental health treatment to patients at home in Melbourne.

"It's been very successful," he said.

"But we still have our inpatient beds; in fact, we don't have enough of them."

Patrick McGorry says programs offering mental health treatment at home have been successful in Victoria. (Supplied: Dr Patrick McGorry)

Dr McGorry said while it was reasonable that patients in Kempsey could adequately access inpatient services from Port Macquarie Base Hospital, the devil was in the details.

"The sequence has got to be right," he said.

"You need to fund the Hospital in the Home service first, then once that's working, it would be safe to close the beds, not before.

title: Major retirement developments get go-ahead on Queensland coast
text:
Thousands of retirement and relocatable homes are either under construction or have been approved along a regional Queensland coastline known for its pristine beaches and "affordable" lifestyle.

A combined 3,676 individual dwellings have been approved in Bundaberg, 4.5 hours' drive north of Brisbane, by the council in the last 12 months.

Among the 18 projects is a $320-million resort-style land lease community at Coral Cove, which includes 504 homes, a clubhouse and wellness facilities minutes from the beach.

Construction has also begun on the first stage of a 437-home gated community at Burnett Heads.

Adrian Puljich, Helen Blackburn and Andrew Coulter turning the sod on the development at Burnett Heads. (Supplied: GemLife)

GemLife managing director and chief executive Adrian Puljich said the $323-million project would be attractive to retirees migrating from south-east Queensland in search of an "affordable" lifestyle.

"We envisaged this project taking approximately six to eight years to deliver from start to finish," he said.

Mr Puljich said homes would start from approximately $700,000 and that there were six designs to choose from.

GemLife said it would also invest $3.7 million in road upgrades, wastewater and sewerage infrastructure for the community.

An impression of GemLife Lighthouse Bay at Burnett Heads. (Supplied: GemLife)

REA Group senior economist Angus Moore said the demographic of people living in the Wide Bay, which included Bundaberg and Hervey Bay, was older than the rest of the state.

"More than 40 per cent of [the] Wide Bay region is already aged over 55, compared to just under 30 per cent of Queensland as a whole," he said.

It also has the one of the highest percentages of over-65s in the country.

Unlocking housing stock

Mr Moore said retirement projects provided those people with an opportunity to downsize and unlock housing stock for younger families.

"Downsizing and allowing our existing houses to be used by those that better suit them would help improve housing affordability," he said.

More than 500 retirement homes will be built at Coral Cove. (ABC Wide Bay: Johanna Marie)

But the area may not be as affordable as it once was, considering house prices in the Wide Bay have more than doubled in the last five years.

The median house price is currently $666,000, compared to the Sunshine Coast's median of $1,259,000 and the Gold Coast's $1,345,000.

Mr Moore believes the market will slow as more homes are built.

"Building more homes is fundamentally the only way that we will start to improve housing affordability sustainably over the long-term," he said.

"In particular, building more homes where people want to live, which is increasingly places like the Wide Bay region."

Strain on health care and aged care

Bundaberg resident Sheryl Miedecke agreed more retirement homes were needed but was concerned about the added pressure on the health care and aged care sectors.

Sheryl Miedecke says there is a shortage of health professionals in Bundaberg. (ABC Wide Bay: Johanna Marie)

"I think it's a good thing to expand and have new people coming here, but whether they've got all the facilities to provide for retirees is the other thing," she said.

"That's a bit of a worry."

Bundaberg Regional Council has not received any development applications for new nursing homes, nor have any been included within the recently approved retirement projects.

"We certainly do need more nursing home developments … it is one of the things that I do talk to investors and developers about," Mayor Helen Blackburn said.

"Everything from student accommodation all the way through to nursing homes and increasing the size of our cemeteries — we need to be looking after everyone, right from the beginning all the way through to the end."

Bundaberg Mayor Helen Blackburn launched a petition calling for the sacking of the chief executive and board of the Friendly Society Private Hospital. (ABC Wide Bay: Johanna Marie)

The council has obtained funding under the state government's Residential Activation Fund for six critical infrastructure projects to support the growth.

That includes $7.7 million to go towards the $9.6 million Millbank Wastewater Treatment Plant.

Mr Puljich said the confidence in the Bundaberg region, including the prospect of a new public hospital, would drive further investment.

"We're very excited to see Bundaberg grow over the next decade and beyond," he said.

"With so much opportunity and so much investment, not just in seniors housing but across agriculture, general housing and, indeed, medical facilities."

title: Kerr set to be fit for Matildas despite Chelsea omission
text:
Sam Kerr will miss Chelsea's Women's Champions League match against Barcelona, just days after the club said she was likely to play.

Chelsea manager Sonia Bompastor said the 32-year-old Matildas captain would not be in the squad because it was part of her planned rehabilitation after her long-term anterior cruciate ligament injury.

Kerr will be sitting in the stands on Friday morning AEDT for a second consecutive match.

She was omitted from Chelsea's Women's Super League squad for last Sunday's match against Liverpool.

On that occasion, Bompastor said of Kerr: "She's fine and she will probably be involved in the game against Barcelona."

Kerr had played her first full 90 minutes for Chelsea in last week's Women's Champions League clash against St Polten in Austria.

She scored twice but Chelsea's medical staff seemingly felt it was still too much for her to feature against European powerhouse Barcelona.

Mary Fowler reveals she experienced racism in France Socceroos star Mary Fowler has shared her experiences of depression and self-harm, as well as racism from her teammates, that she endured during her time with Montpellier.

Kerr, though, should be cleared to travel to Australia to link up with the Matildas.

They play two internationals against New Zealand in Gosford (November 28) and Adelaide (December 2).

"Sam is fine, she will probably be going with the national team next week, but she's not available for us again," Bompastor said.

"It's just a case of managing her comeback. She got 90 minutes against St Polten and it was part of the plan for her to rest a little bit after that and not be involved in the following two games."

Earlier this week, Matildas coach Joe Montemurro told reporters Kerr was "doing really well".

"She got 90 minutes during the week in the Champions League last week, obviously scoring goals, and that's where we want Sam to be," he said.

"But she still needs to be managed, and we've been in close contact with Chelsea in terms of managing the minutes."

AAP

title: Producing alternative proteins for vegans is not as easy as you think
text:
Demand for a new generation of food products called "alternative proteins" is forecast to triple as the global population rises, but startup companies in Australia say they cannot get the finance they need to establish the industry here.

Ingrid Appleqvist from the CSIRO's Food Innovation Centre said the lack of venture capital is a problem for many start-ups, along with a shortage of qualified staff and infrastructure needed to scale up.

The sector is fractured, she said, because 99 per cent of the businesses are small.

"[Food manufacturing is] the biggest manufacturing industry in Australia … but it's made up of tens of thousands of small to medium enterprises," Ms Appleqvist said.

CSIRO's Ingrid Appleqvist says Australia lacks qualified staff and infrastructure needed to scale up. (Supplied: CSIRO)

Start-ups need "off take" agreements to attract capital, but they often struggle to find buyers for their produce when their manufacturing facilities are still in the pilot phase.

Sydney company All G is among those heading overseas to access the high tech plant needed to make alternative proteins.

Chief scientist Jared Raynes said they want to expand their operation in Australia but there are limitations.

"It's really challenging to scale up because the infrastructure just doesn't exist in Australia," he said.

All G produce lactoferrin, a key ingredient in baby formula.

It usually comes from cows milk, but All G claims it can be produced much more efficiently by inserting the gene that produces lactoferrin into a special yeast.

"We do this in a bioreactor, a fancy type of fermenter, in a process not too dissimilar to brewing beer," Mr Raynes said.

They use sugar as a feedstock and potatoes as a source of proteins, and no animal products are used in this process.

"It usually takes 10,000 litres of milk to produce one kilogram of lactoferrin, [but] we can produce one kilogram with less than a thousand litres using fermentation," Mr Raynes said.

Jared Raynes of All G says Australia's pilot plants do not meet his company's needs. (Supplied: All G)

Precision fermenters take microorganisms like yeast, bacteria and fungi, together with a feed stock, and turns them into egg proteins, enzymes, flavours, colours, fats and oils.

A precision fermentation plant has been built in Tasmania and two pilot plants are due to open next year, one in Werribee in Victoria and a second at Mackay in Queensland.

But Jared Raynes said they do not meet his company's needs.

As a result, All G has signed a partnership with a German food company to access a plant there.

Industry lobby group Cellular Agriculture Australia claims producing food this way requires less water and land, results in less emissions and does not cause deforestation and biodiversity loss.

But scientists warn that full life cycle assessment studies on the entire supply chain for alternative protein products are "very limited [and] the impacts of microbe-derived proteins and cultured meat have not been fully assessed".

What are alternative proteins?

Sausages are an example of alternative protein products, this one made mainly from soy. (Supplied: Food Frontiers)

Alternative proteins are being promoted as a possible solution to feed a growing world population.

Products include meat and seafood substitutes and specialised food ingredients made from soy, peas, hemp seeds and ancient grains like quinoa.

There are emerging products as well using insect-based ingredients and meat cultivated from animal cells or produced via fermentation.

In its report on the plant protein industry an independent think tank on alternative proteins in Australia and New Zealand, Food Frontier, reported the value of global plant protein ingredients was more than $24 billion in 2024 and was expected to triple by 2032.

The Grains & Legumes Nutrition Council surveys 2,900 Australian supermarket products, and their audits from 2022 to 2024 show 12 per cent had some plant protein ingredients, particularly in plant-based food and beverage products.

Australian market too small

Australia currently has six plant protein ingredient manufacturers, but most of them are limited in scale and capacity.

Manildra has a plant in Nowra in New South Wales which processes a million tonnes of wheat annually and turns it into concentrates, isolates, flours and starches that go into plant products.

Integra is a plant protein manufacturer based in SA, one of six alternative protein plants across the country. (Supplied: Food Frontiers)

Five new plants have been established in the last six years in Victoria (Essantis), Western Australia (Wide Open Agriculture), Victoria (Australian Plant Proteins), Tasmania (Hemp Harvests) and South Australia (Integra Foods).

Unlike traditional flour mills or pressing plants, these plants use a process called fractionation to concentrate and extract the primary protein ingredients from the flours of cereals, pulses and oilseeds.

Plant-based patties look like meat but are made from completely vegan ingredients. (ABC News: Cam Lang)

The Grains & Legumes Nutrition Council found the need for plant protein ingredients is expected to grow because food service companies are looking for high fibre, protein-rich foods for the health care sector in particular.

Despite that, Professor Brent Kaiser from Sydney University said the market was just not big enough to attract venture capital in Australia because alternative proteins were not a high priority for the average shopper.

"Until consumers have a better understanding of food security, and they choose to buy an alternative protein because it's sustainably produced, the market will remain small," he said.

title: McLaren boss tips 'forlorn' Piastri to fight back in Las Vegas Grand Prix
text:
McLaren expects Oscar Piastri to regain form in the final three races of the F1 championship, despite the Australian trailing teammate Lando Norris on the drivers' standings.

Norris, who won the two most recent races in Brazil and Mexico, leads the championship on 390 points ahead of this weekend's Las Vegas Grand Prix.

Piastri is 24 points behind his McLaren stablemate, having led the standings earlier this season.

The Melburnian has failed to reach the podium in his past five races, prompting ex-world champion Damon Hill to suggest the 24-year-old is struggling.

"Oscar suddenly looks a bit forlorn, a bit under pressure," Hill recently said.

But McLaren chief executive Zak Brown defended Piastri in the build-up to the Las Vegas Grand Prix.

"Oscar's definitely fighting back," Brown said.

"I think one of his greatest strengths is he just gets in the zone."

McLaren orders part of 'perfect storm' that began Piastri's F1 form slump Oscar Piastri says the Azerbaijan Grand Prix weekend was the worst of his racing career and has hinted McLaren team orders may have played a part in it.

But Brown also expressed confidence in Great Britain's Norris, who is chasing his first championship.

"I've never seen Lando in a better place," Brown said.

The championship could be a two-driver duel between the McLaren pair by the conclusion of the Las Vegas Grand Prix.

Defending champion Max Verstappen cannot afford to lose ground on the drivers' standings, as he trails Norris by 49 points in third place.

McLaren has already clinched the constructors' championship, leaving Brown excited about the prospect of claiming both titles in the same season for the first time this century.

"I'd love to be in a position where we leave this race and I know a papaya [McLaren] car is going to be the drivers' champion," Brown said.

"Last weekend in Brazil was great, because Lando extended his lead, but the glass-half-empty side is … it got closer between Max and Oscar.

"What we really want to do is not just win the drivers' championship. We want to finish first and second."

AAP/Reuters

title: Australia news LIVE: Trump signs bill to release all Epstein files; Liberals want ‘Australian values’ screening for new migrants
text:
Fund manager Magellan says its head of global equities, Arvid Streimann, has resigned amid an internal investigation in an alleged relationship with a junior employee.

Magellan Financial Group told the ASX on Thursday that Streimann had resigned after an Australian Financial Review report about an investigation into an alleged relationship published last night.

Magellan’s head of global equities, Arvid Streimann, has resigned.

“This had been separately brought to our attention and is under internal investigation,” Magellan said in an ASX statement.

“MFG confirms that Arvid Streimann has resigned, effective 19 November 2025.”

“MFG remains committed to ensuring appropriate workplace standards in line with its values.”

The AFR report said Magellan was investigating Streimann over an alleged relationship with a junior female employee.

title: Aureka strikes record grades in Victoria as Comstock gold lights up
text:
Aureka’s Comstock gold project in Victoria continues to turn heads with the company unwrapping a suite of assays that not only validate earlier sightings of visible gold but also deliver the highest grades ever recorded at the operation.

The latest numbers, pulled from diamond drill core glinting with coarse free gold, showcase a mineralised system rich in sulphides and structural pathways, and one that is rapidly expanding beyond the limits of the current JORC Resource.

St Arnaud Comstock visible gold with galena and sphalerite in drill hole 25NED002.

The standout headline maker comes from drill hole 25NED002, where Aureka cut 1 metre at a scorching 65.37 grams per tonne gold from 116.2m. The interval includes a 0.3m slice carrying an eye-watering 109g/t gold – the highest individual assay the company has seen at Comstock to date. The same zone also returned almost half a metre grading 65.4g/t gold, underlining a robust high-grade component rather than a one-off spike.

These new assays form part of Aureka’s targeted drilling along the Comstock shear zone – the backbone structure controlling gold emplacement in the district. Mineralisation is tightly associated with quartz reefs carrying arsenopyrite, pyrite, galena and sphalerite, a classic sulphide-rich signature for the St Arnaud Goldfields. The company notes that all of the latest intercepts sit outside of the current resource footprint, pushing the known mineralised system outwards by as much as 100 metres and strengthening the case for a significant resource upgrade.

title: Adam Liaw’s kingfish ceviche bowls
text:
Step 1 Heat your oven to 180C fan-forced (200C conventional) and place the sweet potatoes directly on the racks of the oven. Roast for 50 minutes until tender, then allow to rest. Once cool, split open and scoop out the insides.

Step 2 Combine the kingfish with the coriander, red onion, olive oil, lime juice and season well with salt.

title: Weatherald and Doggett to debut for Australia in Ashes opener
text:
Perth: Jake Weatherald and Brendan Doggett will debut for Australia in the first Ashes Test in Perth.

Australia’s players were informed of the team ahead of their final training session on Thursday, according to two sources with knowledge of discussions.

Tasmania’s Jake Weatherald will debut for Australia. Credit: Getty Images

Weatherald’s selection will mean Marnus Labuschagne bats at No.3 on his return to the Test team, while Cameron Green is expected to edge out Beau Webster as the all-rounder.

Steve Smith will confirm the XI later on Thursday.

title: Stress fractures have derailed our quicks. An expert reveals how to diminish them
text:
As a spotlight is shone on Australia’s fast bowling, a leading physiotherapist has revealed how the next generation can be protected from a common plight.

Dr Kevin Sims, who spent 20 years working with Cricket Australia and Queensland Cricket, describes back stress fractures as a problem that cannot be avoided completely, due to the balancing act required to prepare for elite-level bowling while managing recovery times.

Cameron Green and speed demon Lance Morris have had surgery in the past year after repeated issues, with Green only returning to bowling on the eve of the Ashes series beginning on November 21.

Lance Morris, Cameron Green and Callum Vidler are three pacemen to suffer back stress fractures in the past 12 months. Credit: Getty

Queensland teenage tearaway Callum Vidler is rehabilitating, but has not had surgery, having been earmarked for higher honours since his heroics at the 2024 under-19s One-Day World Cup.

title: How did that happen? The data behind the Wallabies’ dramatic slide
text:
The Wallabies haven’t scored more than 19 points in a Test since racking up 24 against New Zealand in Auckland in the opening Bledisloe Cup clash. The points conceded has also blown out by an average of four a game, leaving an average losing margin of 10 points a game. With a struggling attack, tries have dried up, falling from 3.6 a Test to 1.7, and they’re also conceding an average of one more per Test. Most tellingly, the Wallabies’ ability to score points in the second half has drastically fallen away. Though far from ideal, Australia had developed a habit of giving up a big deficit in the first halves of many of their Tests earlier in the year, but then fought back late to either win or lose narrowly.

But that second-half capacity has almost evaporated. From an average of more than 15 second-half points in the opening eight Tests, the Wallabies have averaged less than five points in the Bledisloe Cup and on the spring tour. They didn’t score a single point in the second half against England. By contrast, their rivals have run up 98 second-half points at an averaged 16 a Test. Injuries and the unavailability of players have been factors, of course, with the Wallabies’ depth – and bench strength – eroded with key men being lost throughout the year. Star fullback Tom Wright was a big loss, and so too Tate McDermott. Jake Gordon’s injury was covered by Nic White until the veteran No.9 finally retired for good. Rob Valetini struggled with injury throughout the year.

The Wallabies cycled through multiple five-eighths, too, with Noah Lolesio lost early and Tom Lynagh also in and out of the squad. James O’Connor, Tane Edmed and Carter Gordon were also used. But the tendency of coach Joe Schmidt to routinely make changes also raised eyebrows. The Wallabies used the same 23-man squad in consecutive Tests just once all year – for the second and third Lions games. Like second-half points, Australia’s discipline was also an issue: they started well in that area before falling away. Having been a major problem in previous years, where penalty counts were stubbornly stuck above 10 a game in most Tests, the Australians appeared to have turned a corner in the three-match Lions series, where they conceded less than 10 penalties in two games. Then in South Africa, the Wallabies gave up only four and six penalties.

In the opening eight Tests, the Wallabies averaged 8.5 penalties a game. But in the six Tests since, that has grown to 11.5 a game, and double-figure counts in four of six games. Most crucially, perhaps, the Wallabies have had players sent from the field in the past six Tests. After not attracting a yellow card in their first seven matches (again a far cry from recent years where one per Test was standard), six yellow cards came in the next seven Tests. The Wallabies have also started making more mistakes – either making it more difficult to win, or putting nails in coffins. When it comes to unforced errors – which is a mistake not brought on by the opposition – the Wallabies were making an average of 4.7 in the opening eight Tests. That has risen to 6.6 a Test since the Wallabies headed to Eden Park hopeful of breaking their Bledisloe Cup drought.

One of the clear areas Australia have struggled in for much of the year, but particularly on the spring tour, is in the air. Though an increasingly common part of top-flight rugby, the attack-minded Wallabies have never been a world-leading team when it comes to contestable kicks; be it defusing them or successfully deploying them. But they hadn’t been known as one of the world’s worst, either. Until this year, that is. The Wallabies have struggled so much to “retain” contestable kicks – the stat covering the ability to either catch a high ball, clean up a spilled catch or force an error from a rival – they’re ranked second-last of the 10 Six Nations-Rugby Championships teams in 2025. Surprisingly, the All Blacks have the worst retention rate.

But the problem is now so acute for the Wallabies that teams are building game plans around contestable kicking. England kicked with good effect in downing the Wallabies at Twickenham, scoring two of four tries from high balls, while Ireland’s win was based on attacking Australia from the air. Loading The Wallabies’ aerial struggle is like a batsman who is known to dislike short-pitched bowling, and thus gets bounced almost every over. So perception plays a big part, and it’ll only change if the Wallabies turn off the retention tap for rivals. The difference can be seen in comparing the Wallabies’ first Test against the Lions and their loss to Ireland. In both games, their rivals sent up 15 contestable kicks. The Lions only managed to retain six of them, and thus dialled back the contestable kick tally to just three in the second Test. But the Irish remarkably retained all 15.

title: Why everyone is getting sick in November
text:
Unseasonably high flu cases are leading to an uptick in visits to NSW emergency departments while COVID infections continue to increase heading into the festive period.

Influenza cases jumped 33 per cent in the first week of November and continued to circulate at higher-than-usual levels last week, the latest NSW Health respiratory surveillance data shows. Around 400 people visited NSW emergency departments with influenza-like illnesses last week.

NSW is experiencing higher-than-usual flu cases in November. Credit: The Sydney Morning Herald

NSW Health’s Dr Jeremy McAnulty said the total number of flu cases this year had been higher than recent years despite the winter flu season peaking lower.

“It’s been quite unusual in that we’ve seen this extended period of flu throughout the season, extending … to where we are almost in summer,” McAnulty said. “Earlier this year we saw the not-unusual increase in summer from what, we believe, was people travelling, and it never went down as far as we’d like.”

title: Fresh off a Dally M-winning season, Roosters captain extends deal to end of 2027
text:
Dual premiership winner and former NSW and Australia captain James Tedesco will remain at the Sydney Roosters through to the end of 2027.

News of Tedesco’s one-year extension came on Thursday, an hour before the skipper was to front the media alongside recruit, Daly Cherry-Evans.

One more year: James Tedesco will remain at the Sydney Roosters until the end of 2027. Credit: James Brickwood

Despite turning 33 in January, Tedesco has never been in better form, and won the Dally M last season by a record margin.

Tedesco’s latest contract will take him through to a 10th season at Bondi Junction, having joined the club from Wests Tigers in 2018 after making his NRL debut in 2012.
